data.value: are power spectral density estimates of X and Y, and
is the cross spectral density estimate of X and Y.

An appropriate amount of overlap will depend on the choice of window and on your requirements. For the default Hann window an overlap of 50% is a reasonable trade off between accurately estimating the signal power, while not over counting any of the data. Narrower windows may require a larger overlap.
is a string or tuple, it is passed to
to generate the window values, which are DFT-even by default. See
for a list of windows and required parameters. If
is array_like it will be used directly as the window and its length must be nperseg. Defaults to a Hann window.

children.type_: str or tuple or array_like, optional

data.value: Length of each segment. Defaults to None, but if window is str or tuple, is set to 256, and if window is array_like, is set to the length of the window.
Number of points to overlap between segments. If
Length of the FFT used, if a zero padded FFT is desired. If
Specifies how to detrend each segment. If
is a string, it is passed as the
function. If it is a function, it takes a segment and returns a detrended segment. If
, no detrending is done. Defaults to 'constant'.
Axis along which the coherence is computed for both inputs; the default is over the last axis (i.e.
Magnitude squared coherence of x and y.
Estimate the magnitude squared coherence estimate, Cxy, of discrete-time signals X and Y using Welch's method.
Generate two test signals with some common features.
Lomb-Scargle periodogram for unevenly sampled data
Power spectral density by Welch's method.
Cross spectral density by Welch's method.
